description.narrative: The Accelerating Localisation through Partnerships project aims to accelerate localisation through the strengthening of local and national leadership of humanitarian response, with activities focussed on four countries - Myanmar, Nepal, Nigeria and South Sudan – but with reach and relevance to many others. The first step is to establish the steering committee, which will then feed into and steer a piece of research looking at partnerships – looking at practical models and asking what are the operational, financial and other business components of partnerships that are conducive to localisation and what are not. Workshops with local partners will then help distil and validate the findings and recommendations. In phase two, the findings of this research will be piloted and tested to fine tune the initial findings which will then feed into national localisation frameworks in each country. These will make locally relevant recommendations to speed up localisation. These four frameworks will then be gathered into a pathway for localisation presented to the Grand Bargain, providing practical guidance to all signatories on how to scale up their partnerships that support localisation.

The effectiveness of humanitarian action will be increased through strengthening local and national leadership in humanitarian response: A partnership model that supports effective localisation is locally developed A Localisation framework is established and local NGO leadership in humanitarian coordination structures is supported Evidence based 'Pathways for localisation' based on effective partnerships is developed and disseminated among the Grand Bargain Signatories.
